content.raw:
Ah, okay.

Then getting back to Shane's question:

It seems that our search for CPPZMQ isn't concerned about versioning the way our search for ZeroMQ is. We could make CPPZMQ a meta-package that finds both `zmq.hpp` and the `ZeroMQ` package if we introduce some versioning into the CPPZMQ find-module. I'd be okay with that, although the current scheme is simpler.

The drawback to the current scheme is that we need to make sure we call `ign_find_package(ZeroMQ ... )` before we call `ign_find_package(CPPZMQ ...)`. This is not ideal, but it also isn't terribly difficult to maintain.

I'm okay with either solution and don't have a strong preference.
content.html:
Ah, okay.

Then getting back to Shane's question:

It seems that our search for CPPZMQ isn't concerned about versioning the way our search for ZeroMQ is. We could make CPPZMQ a meta-package that finds both zmq.hpp and the ZeroMQ package if we introduce some versioning into the CPPZMQ find-module. I'd be okay with that, although the current scheme is simpler.

The drawback to the current scheme is that we need to make sure we call ign_find_package(ZeroMQ ... ) before we call ign_find_package(CPPZMQ ...). This is not ideal, but it also isn't terribly difficult to maintain.

I'm okay with either solution and don't have a strong preference.

content.raw:
cppzmq is included in the debian package, but it comes from a different repository:

* https://github.com/zeromq/cppzmq

it's not included in the homebrew zeromq package for example

I think it worked because it happens to be in the right search path, but if the file was deleted the build would fail

* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/src/1a9c29ac2b91d134367fb268e384540bfd69f397/src/NodeShared.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#NodeShared.cc-21

content.raw:
More broadly, what's the role of the CPPZMQ package, and what does it provide that we don't get from ZeroMQ? Is ZeroMQ just a C library, while CPPZMQ provides C++ bindings for it?

In the `ign-cmake` branch of `ign-transport` it looks like we aren't even using the CPPZMQ package right now. In fact, `ign-transport` builds just fine (on Ubuntu, at least), without even searching for CPPZMQ.

More broadly, what's the role of the CPPZMQ package, and what does it provide that we don't get from ZeroMQ? Is ZeroMQ just a C library, while CPPZMQ provides C++ bindings for it?

In the ign-cmake branch of ign-transport it looks like we aren't even using the CPPZMQ package right now. In fact, ign-transport builds just fine (on Ubuntu, at least), without even searching for CPPZMQ.

content.raw: Ah yeah, we always need to be wary of which version of the cmake documentation we're looking at. Unfortunately, Google always seems to go directly to `3.0` when we really want `3.5`.
content.html: Ah yeah, we always need to be wary of which version of the cmake documentation we're looking at. Unfortunately, Google always seems to go directly to 3.0 when we really want 3.5.

content.raw:
Looks like they moved away from uppercase version. The [cmake 3.2](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.2/module/FindPackageHandleStandardArgs.html) version of the page says `the two possible names are FooBar_FOUND and FOOBAR_FOUND. It is recommended to use the original case version.`

In [cmake 3.5](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.5/module/FindPackageHandleStandardArgs.html) it says `Result variables of both names are always set for compatibility.` 

Based on that I'd say the uppercase variable is for compatibility with old cmake code, which doesn't apply here.
content.html:
Looks like they moved away from uppercase version. The cmake 3.2 version of the page says the two possible names are FooBar_FOUND and FOOBAR_FOUND. It is recommended to use the original case version.

In cmake 3.5 it says Result variables of both names are always set for compatibility.

Based on that I'd say the uppercase variable is for compatibility with old cmake code, which doesn't apply here.

content.raw:
Oh, you're correct!

Apparently that function is inconsistent with the behavior of [find_package](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.5/command/find_package.html):

> Finds and loads settings from an external project. <package>_FOUND will be set to indicate whether the package was found.

~~My best guess is that they make it different to avoid collisions, but I don't imagine that would accomplish much since many find-modules use all uppercase package names anyway. I guess this is just an unfortunate inconsistency in cmake.~~
content.html:
Oh, you're correct!

Apparently that function is inconsistent with the behavior of find_package:

Finds and loads settings from an external project. <package>_FOUND will be set to indicate whether the package was found.

My best guess is that they make it different to avoid collisions, but I don't imagine that would accomplish much since many find-modules use all uppercase package names anyway. I guess this is just an unfortunate inconsistency in cmake.

content.raw: Oh, but `find_package_handle_standard_args` also allows you to specify `FOUND_VAR` to whatever you want, so you can make it `<package>_FOUND` if you choose. I would guess the all-uppercase default behavior is to accommodate the old-fashioned variable style.
content.html: Oh, but find_package_handle_standard_args also allows you to specify FOUND_VAR to whatever you want, so you can make it <package>_FOUND if you choose. I would guess the all-uppercase default behavior is to accommodate the old-fashioned variable style.

content.raw:
My reading of the cmake documentation indicates the `find_package_handle_standard_args` sets the all upper case version of `ZEROMQ_FOUND`.

"If the variables <var1> to <varN> are all valid, then <UPPERCASED_NAME>_FOUND will be set to TRUE."
content.html:
My reading of the cmake documentation indicates the find_package_handle_standard_args sets the all upper case version of ZEROMQ_FOUND.

"If the variables <var1> to <varN> are all valid, then <UPPERCASED_NAME>_FOUND will be set to TRUE."

content.raw:
`find_package_handle_standard_args` will create a `<package>_FOUND` variable where the case of `<package>` matches what was passed into `find_package(~)`, which in this case will be `ZeroMQ`. The only motivation for the all-uppercase variable is to allow end-users to use non-standard variables.

This find-module is only for internal use, so supporting non-standard internal use does not seem desirable to me.
content.html:
find_package_handle_standard_args will create a <package>_FOUND variable where the case of <package> matches what was passed into find_package(~), which in this case will be ZeroMQ. The only motivation for the all-uppercase variable is to allow end-users to use non-standard variables.

This find-module is only for internal use, so supporting non-standard internal use does not seem desirable to me.

content.raw: Can anyone explain this comment? What is it that sets `ZEROMQ_FOUND` on Windows, and why would it be different from other platforms? The `<prefix>_FOUND` variable that gets automatically generated by cmake will have `<prefix>` match the case of the package name as it was given to `find_package(~)`.
content.html: Can anyone explain this comment? What is it that sets ZEROMQ_FOUND on Windows, and why would it be different from other platforms? The <prefix>_FOUND variable that gets automatically generated by cmake will have <prefix> match the case of the package name as it was given to find_package(~).

content.raw:
It looks like the answer is to create an imported target and set `IMPORTED_LOCATION_DEBUG` and `IMPORTED_LOCATION_RELEASE` to the debug and release library paths respectively. 

~~We might also want to set `IMPORTED_LOCATION` to some default for the sake of completeness.~~

From [CMake documentation](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.5/prop_tgt/IMPORTED_LOCATION.html):

> Projects may skip IMPORTED_LOCATION if the configuration-specific property IMPORTED_LOCATION_<CONFIG> is set.
content.html:
It looks like the answer is to create an imported target and set IMPORTED_LOCATION_DEBUG and IMPORTED_LOCATION_RELEASE to the debug and release library paths respectively.

We might also want to set IMPORTED_LOCATION to some default for the sake of completeness.

From CMake documentation:

Projects may skip IMPORTED_LOCATION if the configuration-specific property IMPORTED_LOCATION_<CONFIG> is set.

content.raw: We should create an imported target for ZeroMQ so that our packages can be relocatable, but I have to confess that I don't know offhand how to create an imported target that contains both debug and release information. That might require some investigation, so we don't need to block this PR on that, but we should make sure to do it before too long.
content.html: We should create an imported target for ZeroMQ so that our packages can be relocatable, but I have to confess that I don't know offhand how to create an imported target that contains both debug and release information. That might require some investigation, so we don't need to block this PR on that, but we should make sure to do it before too long.

content.html: Is there a reason we use ZeroMQ_LIBRARY as a middle-man variable instead of using ZeroMQ_LIBRARIES throughout the find-module?

content.raw: I'm somewhat concerned about the `mt` here, because my gut is telling me that it probably refers to the static runtime `/MT`. How certain are we that we want to use a static runtime version of ZeroMQ on Windows? Depending on how ZeroMQ gets used, using a static runtime version of the library could easily result in unexpected seg faults.
content.html: I'm somewhat concerned about the mt here, because my gut is telling me that it probably refers to the static runtime /MT. How certain are we that we want to use a static runtime version of ZeroMQ on Windows? Depending on how ZeroMQ gets used, using a static runtime version of the library could easily result in unexpected seg faults.

content.raw: This is redundant with the printout of `ign_find_package(~)`. If we want to explicitly say that we're looking for `ifaddrs.h`, we can use `ign_find_package( ... PRETTY ifaddrs.h ...)` so that `ign_find_package(~)` will print it out like this.
content.html: This is redundant with the printout of ign_find_package(~). If we want to explicitly say that we're looking for ifaddrs.h, we can use ign_find_package( ... PRETTY ifaddrs.h ...) so that ign_find_package(~) will print it out like this.
